Name: Ampicillin Resistance Gene ("AmpR")
Summarized Function: The ampicillin resistance gene, commonly referred to as bla, encodes the enzyme β-lactamase, which inactivates ampicillin and other β-lactam antibiotics, allowing for the survival of bacteria carrying the plasmid in the presence of these antibiotics.
Description: The bla gene originates from the plasmid of E. coli and produces β-lactamase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes the β-lactam ring of ampicillin, rendering it inactive. This gene is widely used as a selectable marker in plasmid vectors to facilitate the identification and isolation of successfully transformed bacterial cells. In plasmid vectors, the bla gene is typically placed under a strong promoter to ensure adequate expression of the β-lactamase enzyme.
Notes: The presence of the bla gene allows for selection of bacteria that have successfully taken up the plasmid. When ampicillin is added to the growth medium, only those bacteria that carry the plasmid with the bla gene will grow. It's important to ensure that the antibiotic concentration is optimized to select against non-transformed cells while allowing transformed cells to grow.
